importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Tel Aviv soccer derby cancellation due to violent riots, highlighting a significant public safety event in Israeli sports culture.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time of the article's publication indicates the immediacy and recency of the events, emphasizing the real-time nature of public reaction and police response.

keyTakeAways: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder, with injuries to 12 civilians and three police officers.
Police cited the endangerment of human life as the reason for canceling the match, citing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades thrown by fans.
Hapoel criticized the police response, claiming it resembled a military confrontation rather than a sporting event and accused authorities of overreach.

The incident follows prior security concerns involving Maccabi fans, including a ban in England for a Europa League match due to violence, which drew criticism from UK leaders like Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
The UK government acknowledged the concerns over violence in Tel Aviv and stated it is working to understand the circumstances and is committed to ensuring security for Jewish communities.
Maccabi has not publicly commented beyond confirming the match cancellation, while the Israeli Police confirmed 9 arrests and 16 detentions for questioning.

namedEntities.name: Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Israel where the soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi took place
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the match and the center of the violent riots, highlighting urban conflict and fan behavior in a major Israeli cultural hub.

namedEntities.name: Hapoel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Tel Aviv-based soccer club involved in the derby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hapoel was directly involved in the derby and criticized police actions, asserting that the response was disproportionate and militarized.

namedEntities.name: Maccabi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Tel Aviv-based soccer club involved in the derby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maccabi was one of the rival teams in the derby and faced security concerns, though it did not publicly respond beyond confirming cancellation.

namedEntities.name: Bloomfield Stadium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The shared stadium where the derby was to be played
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue was the site of fan clashes and police intervention, underscoring the location of the public disorder and match cancellation.

namedEntities.name: Israel Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency responsible for the event
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The police made the decision to cancel the match, citing public safety and injuries, and were criticized by Hapoel for overreacting.

namedEntities.name: Ben Church
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The CNN journalist who reported the article
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The author of the article, providing credibility and source attribution to the reporting of the incident.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The news organization reporting the story
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The source of the article, indicating the global visibility and dissemination of the event to international audiences.

namedEntities.name: Aston Villa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An English football club where Maccabi fans were banned from attending a Europa League match
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue of a prior incident where Maccabi fans were banned, showing a pattern of security concerns across international matches.

namedEntities.name: West Midlands Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The UK police force that banned Maccabi fans from attending a match at Aston Villa
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UK law enforcement body that initiated the ban due to security risks, linking the Tel Aviv incident to international precedent.

namedEntities.name: Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The UK Prime Minister who criticized the ban on Maccabi fans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key political figure who condemned the UK police decision, reflecting international political response to fan violence concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder at Bloomfield Stadium, with 12 civilians and three police officers injured. Police claimed the match was canceled due to danger to human life, citing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades thrown by fans. Hapoel criticized the police response, calling it militarized and out of proportion. The incident follows prior security concerns, including a ban on Maccabi fans from attending a Europa League game at Aston Villa in England, which sparked backlash from UK leaders like Prime Minister Keir Starmer. The UK government acknowledged the violence in Tel Aviv and is seeking to understand the situation while emphasizing the need for fan safety and community inclusion.
title: Tel Aviv Soccer Derby Canceled by Police Due to 'Violent Riots'
